body.p: The examples on this page show how poorly-written ESQL that fails to sanitize input data can be made to perform actions other than the intended ones.
Randall Munroe's XKCD comic from 2007 is one well-known illustration of this:
and the approach shown in this comic is used below in the first set of examples. The exact text is different due to using ESQL, but the concept is the same.

Note that well-written ESQL does not suffer from most of these issues even if data is not sanitized, as the data is normally passed in via ODBC parameters rather than simply appending the input data as text in an SQL string. The second set of examples show this in action.

This form queries user ID numbers for a single user name provided in the form. Valid values include firstUser and secondUser but the code does not sanitize the data. As a result, using a value of *' OR T.name IN (SELECT name from USERDATA);-- will cause the code to return all the values in the database.

This form also queries user ID numbers for a single user name provided in the form. Valid values include firstUser and secondUser but the code does not sanitize the data. As a result, using a value of firstUser' OR T.name = CAST((PASSTHRU('INSERT INTO ABC(A) VALUES(1)') = PASSTHRU('DROP TABLE STUDENTS')) AS CHARACTER CCSID 1208)-- will cause the code to attempt to insert the specified data into the table ABC and will also attempt to drop the STUDENTS table.
